description: From Middle French tube, from Latin tubus (“tube, pipe”), related to tuba (“long trumpet; war-trumpet”), of obscure ultimate origin, but possibly connected to tībia (“shinbone, reed-pipe”), see there.

entries.meaning: Anything that is hollow and cylindrical in shape.
An approximately cylindrical container, usually with a crimped end and a screw top, used to contain and dispense semiliquid substances.

definitionGroups.group: (Britain, colloquial, often capitalised as Tube, a trademark) The London Underground railway system, originally referred to the lower level lines that ran in tubular tunnels as opposed to the higher ones which ran in rectangular section tunnels. (Often the tube.)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) One of the tubular tunnels of the London Underground.
(Australia, slang) A tin can containing beer.
examples: Beer is also available from bottleshops (or bottle-o's) in cases (or 'slabs') of 24-36 cans (‘tinnies' or ‘tubes') or bottles (‘stubbies') of 375ml each.

entries.meaning: (surfing) A wave which pitches forward when breaking, creating a hollow space inside.
(Canada, US, colloquial) A television. Compare cathode ray tube and picture tube.

verbs.description: tube (third-person singular simple present tubes, present participle tubing, simple past and past participle tubed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To supply with, or enclose in, a tube.
examples: She tubes lipstick in the cosmetics factory.
They tubed down the Colorado River.
